newsitem.title: NORWAY: Hijacker of Bulgarian plane surrenders in Oslo.
newsitem.headline: Hijacker of Bulgarian plane surrenders in Oslo.

text.p: A Palestinian who hijacked a Bulgarian charter airliner to Norway on Tuesday surrendered quickly at Oslo's Gardermoen airport and asked for a lawyer and political asylum, police said.

The man commandeered the Tupolev TU-154 plane on a flight from Beirut to Varna airport near Bulgaria's Black Sea coast and released all 150 passengers in Varna before ordering the crew of eight to take off on the three-hour flight to Oslo.
About 45 minutes after the plane touched down at the cordoned-off airport, the man stepped down the gangway, gave himself up and was driven off to jail. No one was hurt.

"The man surrendered at 8.47 p.m. (1847 GMT)," police superintendent Asbjoern Gran told reporters. "He asked for a lawyer. He asked for political asylum. He said there is no weapon on board but we will check for ourselves."
He added that the man would be remanded in custody on Wednesday.

It was not know why the hijacker was seeking asylum in Norway, but the Scandinavian country is a key player in promoting the Middle East peace process, having helped to broker the landmark 1993 Israel-PLO peace pact.

There was no immediate comment from the government on whether the Palestinian would obtain asylum. However, Norway has taken a tough line on hijackers in the past, extradicting them soon after arrival.
"He has not given any political motive," Gran said. "Maybe all he wanted was to get here. He is of Palestinian origin and between 20 and 30 years old. He speaks broken English."

Varna airport director Atanas Atanasov earlier said the hijacker entered the crew cabin with a bomb in his hand 15 minutes before landing at Varna and demanded that the flight continue either to Helsinki or to Oslo. Bulgarian officials identified him as Nadir Abdulah.
One of the passengers said at Varna: "The man had most of his face veiled with a handkerchief and refused to take food or drink during the flight. Before touch-down he became nervous."
In January 1995 Norway extradited three Iranian hijackers to Russia 16 months after they commandeered an Aeroflot airliner on a domestic flight to Oslo.

Last November, a Palestinian woman involved in the 1977 hijacking of a Lufthansa airliner to Mogadishu was put on a plane to Germany after the government rejected her final appeal. Souhaila Andrawes is on trial in Hamburg charged with murder, attempted murder, hijacking, kidnapping and hostage-taking.

Bulgaria has been involved in two recent incidents of threats to airliners. Last week a Turkish plane bound from Vienna to Istanbul landed at Sofia airport after receiving a bomb threat. In March a Turkish Cypriot airliner, hijacked on a flight from northern Cyprus to Istanbul, landed in Sofia to refuel before flying to Munich, where the hijacker was arrested.
